Award.AwardTitle: The Really Big Questions: Science and the Search for Meaning

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
ABSTRACT

This multiplatform media and science center project is designed to engage audiences in humanity's deepest questions like the nature of love, reality, time and death in both scientific and humanistic terms. Project deliverables include 5 hour-long radio programs for broadcast on NPR stations, public events/museum exhibits at the Exploratorium in San Francisco, kiosks in venues throughout the city, and a social media engagement campaign. The audience of the project is large and diverse using mass media and the internet. But the project will specifically target young, online, and minority audiences using various strategies.

The project is designed to help a diverse audience understand the impact of new scientific developments as well as the basic science, technology, engineering and math needed to be responsible, informed citizens. Innovative elements of the project include the unique format of the radio programs that explore complex topics in an engaging and compelling way, the visitor engagement strategy at the Exploratorium, and the social media strategy that reaches niche audiences who might never listen to the radio broadcasts, but find the podcasts and blogs engaging. The Exploratorium will be opening a new building in 2013 and will include exhibits and programs that are testing grounds for this project. This is a new model that aligns the radio content with exhibitions, social media, and in person events at the Exploratorium, providing a unique holistic approach.

The project is designed to inspire people to think and talk about science and want to find out more. The evaluation will measure the impacts on the targeted audiences reached by each of the key delivery methods. Data will be collected using focus groups; intercept interviews with people in public places, and longitudinal panels. The focus will be on 5 targeted audiences (young adults, families with children, non-NPR listeners, underrepresented minorities, and adults without college experience). This comprehensive evaluation will likely contribute important knowledge to the field based on this multiple-platform collaborative model.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Really Big Questions


The Peabody Award-winning SoundVision Productions in partnership with San Francisco’s world famous Exploratorium science center produced The Really Big Questions (TRBQ), a series of enticing broadcasts, videos, podcasts and museum installations that inspired audiences—including people who might not think they cared about science—to think and talk about science and want to find out more. 

The project, which used some of humanity’s most fascinating questions to grab and hold audience attention, included: five hour-long public radio specials; eight videos, including joint TRBQ/The Atlantic productions; forty-four three-to-15-minute podcasts; a 1000-square-foot immersive temporary Exploratorium exhibition that opened May 2015 and several public events as part of the museum’s After Dark program for adults; a TRBQ feature on PRI’s national daily news magazine The World; feature-length TRBQ stories on selected public radio stations; a TRBQ-related middle school workshop; an interactive TRBQ website and rich Facebook, Twitter and Tumblr pages. 

Reactions to TRBQ’s interconnected broadcasts, podcasts and videos (on love, sharing, music, death and storytelling) were “overwhelmingly positive,” with listeners saying everything from “very cool and truly awe-inspiring” and “I love Science!!!” to “It’s a joy to have these ‘really big questions’ pondered for you by all these brilliant individuals. Greatest script that I’ve heard on the radio in a very long time.”

TRBQ got exceptional carriage. While most public radio series are carried by fewer than 100 stations, TRBQ was carried by almost 250, in nine of the top 10 (and 16 of the top 20) markets across the country, reaching between 700,000 and 1 million listeners.  Along with the TRBQ stories on local and regional stations, a TRBQ feature on love was broadcast on PRI’s national daily news magazine The World, which reaches 500,000 listeners.

TRBQ had an impact; all of TRBQ listeners surveyed said the series motivated them to discuss program topics with their friends, classes, book groups or learning communities after the show. The series prompted them to think critically and talk about related issues, listen to programs more than once, conduct online research and share links to TRBQ content with their friends. University professors, high school teachers, hospital workers, prison administrators and the clergy reported using TRBQ in their classes and work. The series inspired everything from an Ohio pastor’s “Share $20 on 20 Day” to a national story-writing contest.

TRBQ’s online component also took off and our rich media collaborations inspired edgy new ways to present science online. Our first project with The Atlantic, “We Are Dead Stars,” went viral on Facebook, where it’s gotten more than 4.3 million views. It was also named a Vimeo Staff Pick, drawing more than 150,000 views on that site alone, and was “THE TOP most viewed original video of the last year” on The Atlantic site, which gets 17.1 million page views per month. When PRI added the TRBQ podcast to its iTunes podcasts, the number of downloads quadrupled in an afternoon, and within two months, it got 20,000 downloads per episode.
